[[pt:Sa√∫de de Jo√£o Paulo II]]

[[Costa Rica]] provides [[universal health care]] to its citizens and permanent residents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cehat.org/rthc/paper5.htm | title=Costa Rican Health Care: A Maturing Comprehensive System | last=Connolly | first=Greg | date=December 8, 2002 }}</ref> Costa Rica offers some of the best health care in Central America. Both the private and public health care systems are always being upgraded. New hospitals, new clinics, new machines, and improvement in staff and training. Statistics from the World Health Organization (WHO) frequently place Costa Rica in the top country rankings in the world for long life expectancy. WHO's 2000 survey ranked Costa Rica as having the 36th best health care system, placing it one spot above the United States at the time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Warf|first=Barney|date=2010|title=Do You Know the Way to San Jos√©? Medical Tourism in Costa Rica|url=|journal=Journal of Latin American Geography|volume= 9| issue = 1|pages=51‚Äì66}}</ref> In addition, the UN (United Nations) has ranked Costa Rica‚Äôs public health system within the top 20 worldwide and the number 1 in Latin America.<ref name="bare_url">{{cite web|title=Health Care in Costa Rica|url=http://tamborhills.com/costa-rica-health-care.html|publisher=Century 21|accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref>
==Costs== In the early 1970s, the Ministry of Heath was heavily subsidized by foreign aid. However, by 1977, health programs had been so successful that US Aid for International Development in the sector was ended, as the country was found "too healthy" to continue being a recipient.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morgan|first=Lynn M.|date=Spring 1987|title=Health without Wealth? Costa Rica's Health System under Economic Crisis|url=|journal=Journal of Public Health Policy|volume= 8| issue = 1|pages=86‚Äì105}}</ref> In 2001, total spending on health care was 7% of GDP, with 3/4 of that being the public sector.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Wealth, Health, and Democracy in East Asia and Latin America|last=McGuire|first=James W.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2010|isbn=978-0-521-13934-2|location=New York|pages=65‚Äì93|chapter=Costa Rica: A Healthy Democracy}}</ref> Currently, costs tend to be much less than doctor, hospital, and prescription costs in the U.S.<ref name="bare_url_a">{{cite web|title=Costa Rica Health Care|url=http://costarica.com/relocation/health-care/|publisher=CostaRica.com|accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref> The country spends one tenth as much per capita on health care as the United States, focusing on preventive care.<ref name=":1">Buettner, Dan. "The World's Happiest Places." ''National Geographic'', Nov. 2017, p. 45.</ref>
==Public== [[File:CCSS - Costa Rica.gif|thumb|[[Costa Rican Social Security Fund]] Logo]] {{see also|List of hospitals in Costa Rica}} The '''[[Costa Rican Social Security Fund]]''' or ''Caja Costarricense de Seguro Social'' (as it is known in Spanish) is in charge of most of the nation's public health sector. Its role in public health (as the administrator of health institutions) is key in Costa Rica, playing an important part in the state's national health policy making. Worker and employer contribution are mandated by law, under the principle of solidarity. Workers need to be cover by a "poliza de riesgo del trabajo" an insurance policy that complements the health care provided by the "Caja" for injuries related to labor risks.
Caja services are guaranteed to all residents, including the uninsured.<ref name=":3">Cercone, James, Etoile Pinder, Jose Pacheco Jimenez, and Rodrigo Bricena. "Impact of Health Insurance on Access, Use, and Health Status in Costa Rica." ''The Impact of Health Insurance in Low-and Middle-Income Countries'', edited by Maria-Luisa Escobar, Charles C. Griffin, and R. Paul Shaw, Brookings Institution Press, Washington, D.C., 2010, pp. 89-105.</ref> In 1989 this was expanded to include undocumented immigrants as well, which constituted up to 8% of the population at the time. The percent of residents with health insurance increased gradually, as the program was originally only intended for urban workers. It was not until 1961 that universal mandatory coverage became a stated goal.<ref name=":2" /> After reaching a peak of 92% coverage in 1990, rates have remained around 88%. 12% of the insured are low-income residents who are eligible to have their coverage paid entirely by the state, based on a means-test. 87% of the uninsured enter a hospital via the emergency room, compared to only 58% of the insured.<ref name=":3" />
Emergency care is provided free of charge to all residents.<ref name=":3" /> This governmental entity's functions encompass both the administrative and functional aspects. It has the obligation (as a public institution) to formulate and execute health programs that are both preventive (such as: [[vaccination]], informational, [[fumigation]], etc.) and healing (such as: [[surgery]], [[radiation therapy]], [[pharmacy]], [[Clinical medicine|clinical]], etc.) in nature.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.ccss.sa.cr/portal/page/portal/Gerencia_Administrativa/Funciones|title=CCSS {{!}} Caja Costarricense de Seguro Social: Funciones|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225102233/http://portal.ccss.sa.cr/portal/page/portal/Gerencia_Administrativa/Funciones|archive-date=25 December 2010}}</ref> Services "are aimed disproportionately" toward underprivileged Nicaraguan and Colombian immigrants and indigenous communities.<ref name=":0" /> Spending is relatively progressive, with the poorest quintile receiving 29% of spending while the richest quintile only receives 11%.<ref name=":2" />
In 2000, 90% of the country's doctors were employed by the public sector, but 1/3 of those also maintained a private practice.<ref name=":2" /> During the decade of the 1990s the percentage of all medical staff (not just doctors) who worked in the private sector increased from 10% to almost 25%.<ref name=":3" /> As more doctors opt for the more profitable field of private practice, especially in relation to medical tourism, the government has resorted to hiring around 100 Cuban doctors annually to work in the public sector, as of 2010.<ref name=":0" />
Alongside universal health care the government also provides basic dental care. However, this does not include most orthodontic procedures, such as braces.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://usaherald.com/costa-rica-dental-clinic-provides-free-dental-care-children-need/|title=Costa Rica Dental Clinic Provides Free Dental Care to Children in Need ‚Äì USA Herald|date=2017-11-13|work=USA Herald|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== EBAIS ===
The Equipos B√°scios de Atenci√≥n Integral en Salud (EBAIS), or Comprehensive Basic Health Care Team, began operating in 1995, under control of the Social Security Fund. The program had been proposed two years earlier by a bipartisan committee of experts set up by the president to redress decreases in the quality of services that had occurred over the preceding decade.<ref name=":2" /> The goal of the program is to ensure that all citizens have access to medical care, including rural residents. EBAIS employees are divided into teams of about five members, including one doctor. Team members visit people at their homes to vaccinate, offer medical advice, check vitals, and dispense medication. They also rectify any standing water situations they observe, which otherwise act as breeding grounds for mosquitoes and their associated diseases.<ref name=":1" /> EBAIS designates certain residences as high-risk due to subs-standard housing and amenities or risky health conditions (eg. teenage pregnancy). Members also address the health of patients' pets, such as ensuring that they are up to date on all necessary vaccinations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.psu.edu/story/338473/2014/12/16/academics/students-travel-costa-rica-study-health-care-system|title=Students travel to Costa Rica to study health care system {{!}} Penn State University|access-date=2017-12-06}}</ref> There are nearly 1,000 teams, each overseeing the health of 3,500-4,000 individuals.<ref name=":3" />
After an original rejection, $9 million was later granted for the creation of EBAIS by the World Bank. The rest of the $50 million price tag was paid for by the Social Security Fund.<ref name=":2" />
The '''Costa Rican Social Security Fund''' is also charged with the administration of the public pension system.
==Private== {{see also|Medical tourism#Costa Rica}} Costa Rica is a popular destination for [[medical tourism]] because of the beautiful surroundings, low costs, abundance of bilingual medical personnel, and medical reputation.<ref>{{cite web| author = Walecia Kinrad| title = Going Abroad to Find Affordable Health Care| publisher = New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/21/health/21patient.html|date = March 20, 2009|accessdate = 2010-03-28 }}</ref> Over 40,000 Americans come to the country annually as medical tourists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thecostaricanews.com/costa-rica-country-loved-expats/|title=Costa Rica: A Country Loved by Expats {{!}} The Costa Rica News|last=Canelo|first=Abelardo|date=2017-12-05|work=The Costa Rica News|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Private insurance plans are available through the government-owned insurance company(INS). Private plans include dental work, optometry, well-visits and annual check-ups. 80% of the costs are covered for prescription drugs, certain medical exams, sick visits and hospitalization. Surgeon and aesthetician costs are covered at full cost. Currently, private medical insurance costs about $60‚Äì$250/month per person, depending on gender, age, other factors.<ref name="bare_url_a" /> Reasons for opting for private health care include shorter wait times and the ability to choose one's doctor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thecostaricanews.com/costa-rica-curious-facts/|title=Costa Rica's Curious Facts {{!}} The Costa Rica News|last=Barrera|first=Gilberto|date=2017-12-04|work=The Costa Rica News|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Around 30% of the population utilizes private health services at least once a year, according to surveys.<ref name=":3" /> Costa Rica has three internationally accredited private hospitals.<ref>{{cite web|author = Chrissie Long|title = Why Rush Limbaugh would go to Costa Rica if Obama's healthcare plan passes|publisher = Christian Science Monitor|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/2010/0311/Why-Rush-Limbaugh-would-go-to-Costa-Rica-if-Obama-s-healthcare-plan-passes|date = March 11, 2010|accessdate = 2010-03-28 }}</ref> The four largest private hospitals in Costa Rica are CIMA in the suburbs of San Jose, Cl√≠nica Biblica in the center of San Jose, Cl√≠nica Cat√≥lica and Hospital Clinica UNIBE in the suburbs of San Jose.<ref name="bare_url" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Health Care in Costa Rica Hospital Cl√≠nica UNIBE (Universidad de Iberoamerica)|url=http://www.costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com/57-hospitals-in-costa-rica-hospital-cl%C3%ADnica-unibe.html|publisher=Plastic Surgery Forums Costa Rica|accessdate=18 May 2012}}</ref> Domestic private health insurance was not legalized until 2006.<ref name=":2" /> International private insurance companies were not allowed to operate in the country until a Free Trade Agreement was signed with the United States in 2009.<ref name=":3" />
==Pharmacy== Many drugs (like birth control pills, high cholesterol medication, migraine medicine, etc.) are available in Costa Rica without a prescription. Many common problems can be accurately diagnosed and treated by pharmacists. Also, most major pharmacies have a doctor on staff. Most Costa Ricans head to the pharmacy first and consult with the pharmacist or doctor on staff; if he or she can not diagnose you or believe you need further treatment, you will be sent to the hospital.<ref name="bare_url_a" />
== Childbirth == [[Ng√∂be]] women are considered "sick" (''bren'') while pregnant, and pregnancy is almost never discussed, even during birth. When the baby is deemed healthy, people consider it safe to acknowledge the pregnancy. Many women have traditionally given birth in their homes, with the help of their mother or a [[midwife]]. The government has established some women's clinics in Ngobe territory, seeking to improve women's health. The staff of San Vito Hospital, [[Coto Brus (canton)|Coto Brus]] have had to adapt some of their practices to accommodate the women's culture and to encourage traditional midwives to come to the hospital.<ref>{{cite news |title=NG√ñBE WOMEN‚ÄôS KEY TO CHILDBIRTH IN SAN VITO HOSPITAL: TRADITIONAL MIDWIVES, SPIRITUAL LEADERS AND SPECIAL DIET |url=http://healthsystemsresearch.org/hsr2018/hsg-media-fellows/ngobe-womens-key-to-childbirth-in-san-vito-hospital-traditional-midwives-spiritual-leaders-and-special-diet/ |accessdate=28 November 2018 |publisher=Health Systems Research |date=2018}}</ref>
Abortion in Costa Rica is restricted to situations that preserve the life or physical health of the mother. Abortions are illegal in cases of rape or incest, for social or economic reasons or when the unborn child suffers from medical problems or birth defects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pregnantpause.org/lex/world02.htm|title=Summary of Abortion Laws Around the World|publisher=}}</ref> {{main|Abortion in Costa Rica}}
==Smoking== {{main|Smoking in Costa Rica}} It is illegal to smoke in all public vehicles, public buildings and recreation areas such as parks, stadia etc.

The concept of excessive [[selfishness]] has been recognized throughout history. The term "[[narcissism]]" is derived from the [[Greek mythology]] of [[Narcissus (mythology)|Narcissus]], but was only coined at the close of the nineteenth century.
Since then, narcissism has become a household word; in analytic literature, given the great preoccupation with the subject, the term is used more than almost any other'.<ref>[[Neville Symington]], ''Narcissism: A New Theory'' (London 1990) p. 5</ref>
The meaning of narcissism has changed over time. Today narcissism "refers to an interest in or concern with the self along a broad continuum, from healthy to pathological ... including such concepts as self-esteem, self-system, and self-representation, and true or false self".<ref name=Ronningstam>{{cite book|last=Ronningstam, Ed.|first=Elsa|title=Disorders of Narcissism: Diagnostic, Clinical, and Empirical Implications|year=2000|publisher=Jason Aronson|isbn=978-0765702593|page=53|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DHDD3yoVixUC&dq=%22Walter+Mitty%22+narcissism&lr=&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref>
==Before Freud==
Narcissus was a handsome Greek youth who rejected the desperate advances of the [[nymph]] [[Echo (mythology)|Echo]]. As punishment, he was doomed to fall in love with his own reflection in a pool of water. Unable to consummate his love, Narcissus 'lay gazing enraptured into the pool, hour after hour',<ref>[[Robert Graves]], in Symington, p. 7</ref> and finally pined away, changing into a flower that bears his name, the [[Narcissus (plant)|narcissus]].
The story was retold in Latin by [[Ovid]] in his [[Metamorphoses]], in which form it would have great influence on medieval and Renaissance culture. 'Ovid's tale of Echo and Narcissus...weaves in and out of most of the English examples of the Ovidian narrative poem';<ref>Colin Burrow ed., ''William Shakespeare: The Complete Sonnets and Poems'' (Oxford 2002) p. 19</ref> and 'allusions to the story of Narcissus...play a large part in the poetics of the [[Shakespeare's Sonnets|Sonnets]]'<ref>Burrow ed., p. 127</ref> of Shakespeare. Here the term used was '[[self-love]]...Feed'st thy light's flame with self-substantial fuel'.<ref>Burrow ed., pp. 387 and 383</ref> [[Francis Bacon]] used the same term: 'it is the nature of extreme self-lovers, as they will set a house on fire, and it were but to roast their eggs...those that (as [[Cicero]] says of [[Pompey]]) are ''sui amantes sine rivali''...lovers of themselves without rivals'.<ref>Francis Bacon, ''The Essays'' (Penguin 1985) p. 131</ref>
[[Byron]] at the start of the nineteenth century used the same term, describing how, "Self-love for ever creeps out, like a snake, to sting anything which happens...to stumble on it."<ref>Quoted in Simon Crompton, ''All about Me'' (London 2007) p. 87</ref> while [[Baudelaire]] wrote of 'as vigorous a growth in the heart of natural man as self-love', as well as of those who 'like Narcissuses of fat-headedness...are contemplating the crowd, as though it were a river, offering them their own image'.<ref>Charles Baudelaire, ''The Painter of Modern Life'' (Penguin) p. 49 and p. 109</ref>
By mid-century, however, [[egotism]] was perhaps an equally common expression for self-absorption‚Äî'egotists...made acutely conscious of a self, by the torture in which it dwells'<ref>Malcolm Cowley ed., ''The Portable Hawthorne'' <Penguin 1978) p. 167</ref>‚Äîthough still with 'curious suggestions of the Narcissus legend'<ref>Cowley ed., "Editor's Introduction" p. 9</ref> in the background. At the century's close, the term as we now know it finally emerged, with [[Havelock Ellis]], the English [[sexology|sexologist]], writing a short paper in 1927 on its coining, in which he 'argued that the priority should in fact be divided between himself and [[Paul N√§cke]], explaining that the term "narcissus-like" had been used by him in 1898 as a description of a psychological attitude, and that N√§cke in 1899 had introduced the term ''Narcismus'' to describe a sexual perversion'.<ref>Editor Note, Sigmund Freud, ''On Metapsychology'' (PFL 11) p. 65n1</ref>
The twentieth century has largely defined the concept in psychological terms, with [[Otto Rank]] publishing in 1911 the first psychoanalytical paper specifically concerned with narcissism, linking it to [[vanity]] and self-admiration.<ref name=millon>Millon, Theodore, Personality Disorders in Modern Life, 2004</ref>
==Sigmund Freud== {{Main article|Sigmund Freud}} [[Image:Sigmund Freud, by Max Halberstadt (cropped).jpg|thumb|Sigmund Freud, by Max Halberstadt, 1914]]
[[Ernest Jones]] tells us that 'at a meeting of the Vienna Psycho-Analytical Society on 10 November 1909 [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]] had declared that narcissism was a necessary intermediate stage between auto-erotism and object-love'.<ref>Angela Richards, "Editor's Note", Sigmund Freud, ''On Metapsychology'' (PFL 110 pp. 61-2</ref> The following year in his "Leonardo" he described publicly for the first time how 'the growing youngster...finds his love objects on the path of ''narcissism'', since Greek myths call a youth Narcissus, whom nothing pleased so much as his own mirror image'.<ref>Quoted in Peter Gay, ''Freud; A Life for Our Time'' (London 1989) p. 272</ref> Although Freud only published a single paper exclusively devoted to narcissism called [[On Narcissism|On Narcissism: An Introduction]].,<ref name=freud1>[http://www.english.hawaii.edu/criticalink/narc/guide1.html Freud, Sigmund, On Narcissism: An Introduction], 1914</ref> in 1914, 'Narcissism was soon to take a central place in his thinking'.<ref>Gay, p. 272</ref>
=== Primary narcissism === Freud suggested that exclusive self-love might not be as abnormal as previously thought and might even be a common component in the human [[Psyche (psychology)|psyche]]. He argued that narcissism "is the [[libido|libidinal]] complement to the [[Psychological egoism|egoism]] of the [[instinct]] of [[self-preservation]]," or, more simply, the desire and energy that drives one‚Äôs [[instinct]] to survive. He referred to this as ''primary narcissism''.<ref name=freud1 />
According to Freud, people are born without a sense of themselves as individuals, or [[Id, ego and super-ego#Ego|ego]]. The ego develops during infancy and the early part of childhood, only when the outside world, usually in the form of parental controls and expectations, intrudes upon primary narcissism, teaching the individual about the nature and standards of his [[social environment]] from which he can form the ''[[ego ideal|ideal ego]]'', an image of the perfect [[Self (psychology)|self]] towards which the ego should aspire. 'As it evolved, the ego distanced itself from primary narcissism, formed an ego-ideal, and proceeded to cathect objects'.<ref>[http://www.enotes.com/psychoanalysis-encyclopedia/narcissism-primary Michel Vincent, "Narcissism, Primary"]</ref>
Freud regarded all [[libido|libidinous]] [[Drive theory|drives]] as fundamentally sexual and suggested that ''ego libido'' ([[libido]] directed inwards to the [[Self (psychology)|self]]) cannot always be clearly distinguished from ''object-libido'' (libido directed to persons or objects outside oneself).
An aspect frequently associated with primary narcissism appears in an earlier essay, '[[Totem and Taboo]],'<ref name=freud2>Freud, ''Sigmund, [[Totem and Taboo]]'', 1913</ref> in which Freud describes his observations of children and primitive people. What he observed was called [[magical thinking]], such as the belief that a person can impact reality by wishing or willpower. It demonstrates a belief in the self as powerful and able to change external realities, which Freud believed was part of normal human development.
=== Secondary narcissism === According to Freud, ''secondary narcissism'' occurs when the libido withdraws from objects outside the self, above all the mother, producing a relationship to social reality that includes the potential for [[megalomania]]. 'This megalomania has no doubt come into being at the expense of object-libido....This leads us to look upon the narcissism which arises through the drawing on of object-cathexes as a secondary one, superimposed upon a primary narcissism'.<ref>Freud, ''On Metapsychology'' p. 67</ref> For Freud, while both primary and secondary narcissism emerge in normal human development, problems in the transition from one to the other can lead to pathological narcissistic disorders in adulthood.
"This state of secondary narcissism constituted object relations of the narcissistic type", according to Freud, something he went on to explore further in ''[[Mourning and Melancholia]]''‚Äîconsidered one of Freud's most profound contributions to [[object relations theory]], and constituting the overall principles of object relations and narcissism as concepts.<ref>James S. Grotstein, "Foreword", Symington, pp. x-xi</ref>
=== Narcissism, relationships and self-worth === According to Freud, to care for someone is to convert ego-libido into object-libido by giving some self-love to another person, which leaves less ego-libido available for primary narcissism and protecting and nurturing the self. When that affection is returned so is the libido, thus restoring primary narcissism and self-worth. Any failure to achieve, or disruption of, this balance causes psychological disturbances. In such a case, primary narcissism can be restored only by withdrawing object-libido (also called ''object-love'') to replenish ego-libido.
According to Freud, as a child grows, and his ego develops, he is constantly giving of his self-love to people and objects, the first of which is usually his mother. This diminished self-love should be replenished by the affection and caring returned to him.
==Karen Horney== {{Main article|Karen Horney}} [[Image:Karen Horney 1938.jpg|thumb|Karen Horney]]Karen Horney saw narcissism quite differently from Freud, Kohut and other mainstream [[psychoanalysis|psychoanalytic]] theorists in that she did not posit a primary narcissism but saw the narcissistic personality as the product of a certain kind of early environment acting on a certain kind of temperament. For her, narcissistic needs and tendencies are not inherent in human nature.
Narcissism is different from Horney's other major [[Defence mechanism|defensive strategies]] or solutions in that it is not compensatory. Self-idealization is compensatory in her theory, but it differs from narcissism. All the defensive strategies involve self-idealization, but in the narcissistic solution it tends to be the product of indulgence rather than of deprivation. The narcissist's [[self-esteem]] is not strong, however, because it is not based on genuine accomplishments.<ref name=horney1>Paris, Bernard J, ''Personality and Personal Growth'', edited by Robert Frager and James Fadiman, 1998</ref>
==Heinz Kohut== {{Main article|Heinz Kohut}} Heinz Kohut explored further the implications of Freud's perception of narcissism. He maintained that a child will tend to fantasize about having a grandiose [[Self (psychology)|self]] and ideal parents. He claimed that deep down, all people retain a belief in their own perfection and the perfection of anything they are part of. As a person matures, [[grandiosity]] gives way to [[self-esteem]], and the idealization of the parent becomes the framework for core values. It is when [[psychological trauma]] disrupts this process that the most primitive and narcissistic version of the self remains unchanged. Kohut called such conditions [[narcissistic personality disorder]], 'in which the merging with and detaching from an archaic self-object play the central role...narcissistic union with the idealized self-object'.<ref>Heinz Kohut, ''The Analysis of the Self'' (Madison 1971) p. 282 and pp. 97-8</ref>
Kohut suggested narcissism as part of a stage in normal development, in which caregivers provide a strong and protective presence with which the child can identify that reinforces the child's growing sense of self by mirroring his good qualities. If the caregivers fail to provide adequately for their child, the child grows up with a brittle and flawed sense of self.<ref name=kohut1>Kohut, Heinz, ''The Analysis of the Self'', 1971</ref> 'Kohut's innovative pronouncement...became a veritable manifesto in the United States....The age of "normal narcissism" had arrived'<ref>James L. Grotstein, "Foreword", in Symington, p. xiii</ref>
Kohut also saw beyond the negative and [[pathological]] aspects of narcissism, believing it is a component in the development of resilience, ideals and ambition once it has been transformed by life experiences or analysis<ref name=kohut2>Kohut, Heinz, ''Forms and Transformations of Narcissism'', 1966</ref>‚Äîthough critics objected that his theory of how 'we become attached to ideals and values, instead of to our own archaic selves...fits the individual who escapes from bad inner negativity into idealized objects outside'.<ref>Symington, pp. 108-9</ref>
==Otto Kernberg== {{Main article|Otto Kernberg}} [[File:Otto F. Kernberg, MD.jpg|thumb|Otto F. Kernberg.]] Otto Kernberg uses the term ''narcissism'' to refer to the role of [[Self (psychology)|self]] in the regulation of [[self-esteem]].
He believed normal, infantile narcissism depends on the affirmation of others and the acquisition of desirable and appealing objects, which should later develop into healthy, mature self-esteem. This healthy narcissism depends upon an integrated sense of [[Self (psychology)|self]] that incorporates images of the internalized affirmation of those close to the person and is regulated by the [[super ego]] and [[ego ideal]], internal mental structures that assure the person of his worth and that he deserves his own respect.
The failure of infantile narcissism to develop in this healthy adult form becomes a [[pathology]].<ref name=kernberg>Siniscalco, Raffaele [http://www.psychomedia.it/jep/number12-13/kernberg.htm Narcissism. The American Contribution ‚Äì A Conversation with Otto Kernberg] ''Journal of European Psychoanalysis'', Number 12‚Äì13, Winter‚ÄìFall 2001</ref>
==Object relations theory== {{Main article|Object relations theory}} '[[Melanie Klein]]'s...descriptions of infantile [[omnipotence]] and [[megalomania]] provided important insights for the clinical understanding of narcissistic states. In 1963, writing on the psychopathology of narcissism, [[Herbert Rosenfeld]] was especially concerned to arrive at a better definition of object-relationships and their attendant defense mechanisms in narcissism'.<ref name="Michel Vincent, Narcissism">[http://www.enotes.com/psychoanalysis-encyclopedia/narcissism Michel Vincent, "Narcissism"]</ref>
[[D. W. Winnicott]]'s 'brilliant observations of the mother-child couple [also] throw considerable light on primary narcissism, which in the young child can be viewed as the extension of the mother's narcissism.<ref name="Michel Vincent, Narcissism"/>
==French connections==
[[Jacques Lacan|Lacan]]‚Äîbuilding on Freud's dictum that 'all narcissistic impulses operate from the ego and have their permanent seat in the ego'<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''Case Studies II'' (PFL 9) p. 353</ref>‚Äîused his own concept of the [[mirror stage]] to explore the narcissistic ego in terms of 'the essential structure it derives from its reference to the specular image...narcissism',<ref>Jacques Lacan, ''The Four Fundamental Concepts of Psycho-Analysis'' (London 1994) p. 74</ref> in his battle against [[ego psychology]].
'[[B√©la Grunberger]] drew attention to a double orientation of narcissism‚Äîas both a need for self-affirmation and a tendency to restore permanent dependency. The active presence of narcissism throughout life led Grunberger to suggest treating it as an autonomous factor (1971)'.<ref name="Michel Vincent, Narcissism"/>
'Under the evocative title ''Life Narcissism, Death Narcissism'' (1983), [[Andr√© Green (psychoanalyst)|Andr√© Green]] clarified the conflict surrounding the object of narcissism (whether a fantasy object or a real object) in its relationship to the ego. For Green, it was because narcissism affords the ego a certain degree of independence...that a lethal kind of narcissism must be considered, for the object is destroyed at the beginning of this process'; while in a further analysis, 'Green evokes physical narcissism, intellectual narcissism, and moral narcissism'<ref name="Michel Vincent, Narcissism"/>‚Äîa set of divisions sometimes simplified into that between 'somatic narcissists who are obsessed with the body...[&] cerebral narcissists‚Äîpeople who build up their sense of magnificence out of an innate feeling of intellectual superiority'.<ref>Crompton, pp. 28-9</ref>
==Modern diagnosis== [[Narcissistic personality disorder]] is a condition defined in [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-IV]], but a proposal has been made to remove it from the next edition, [[DSM-5]], instead submerging it as a facet of the antagonism personality type domain.<ref>[http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/Pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=19 Narcissistic Personality Disorder]</ref><ref>[http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=474 Antagonism]</ref>
==Online usage==
The success of the term ''narcissism'' has led to something of an "inflation of meanings....Some in fact exploited it as a handy term of abuse for modern culture or as a loose synonym for bloated self-esteem."<ref>Gay, p. 340</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Malignant narcissism]] * [[Narcissism of small differences]] * [[Narcissistic parents]] * [[Narcissistic rage and narcissistic injury]] * [[Narcissistic supply]] * [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)]] }}
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=40em}}
==Further reading== * Bela Grunberger, ''Narcissism: Psychoanalytic Essays'' (New York 1971) * J. Sandler et al., ''Freud's "On Narcissism: An Introduction"'' (Yale UP, 1991)
==External links== * [http://www.enotes.com/psychoanalysis-encyclopedia/narcissistic-defenses Elsa Schmid-Kitsikis, "Narcissistic Defenses"]
{{Narcissism}}

{{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox scientist | name = John Murray | image =SirJMurrayatwork.jpg | alt=An old bearded man drawing or measuring with a compass. | image_size = | caption = Murray in 1902 | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1841|03|03}} | birth_place = [[Cobourg, Ontario|Cobourg]], [[Canada West]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1914|03|16|1841|03|03}} | death_place = [[Kirkliston]], Midlothian, Scotland | death_cause = [[Car crash]] | nationality = British | fields = oceanography
limnology | workplaces = Challenger Expedition Commission (1872)
Director of the Challenger Expedition Commission (1882)
Established marine laboratories at Granton and Millport | alma_mater = [[Edinburgh University]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = J.Murray | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Makdougall-Brisbane Prize]] {{small|(1884‚Äì86)}}
[[Neill Prize]] {{small|(1877‚Äì80)}}
[[Cullum Geographical Medal]] {{small|(1899)}}
[[Clarke Medal]] {{small|(1900)}}
[[Swedish Society for Anthropology and Geography|Vega Medal]] (1912) | spouse = {{marriage|Isabel Henderson|1889}} | children = 3 daughters, 2 sons {{Cite journal | URL=https://www.jstor.org/stable/20025726|title=Sir John Murray (1841-1914)|journal=Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences|volume=52|issue=13 |year= 1917|pages= 853‚Äì859 }} | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = President of the [[Royal Scottish Geographical Society]] (1898‚Äì1904)
President of the [[Scottish Natural History Society]]
Member of the [[Scottish Meteorological Society]] }} [[File:Sir John Murray's grave, Dean Cemetery.JPG|thumb|Sir John Murray's grave, Dean Cemetery]] '''Sir John Murray''' [[Order of the Bath|KCB]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society of London|FRS]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]] [[FRSGS]] (3 March 1841 ‚Äì 16 March 1914) was a pioneering British [[oceanographer]], [[marine biologist]] and [[limnologist]]. He is considered to be the father of modern oceanography.{{cite book |last1=Waterston |first1=Charles D |last2=Macmillan Shearer |first2=A |title=Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783‚Äì2002: Biographical Index |url=http://www.rse.org.uk/fellowship/fells_indexp2.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061004113303/http://www.rse.org.uk/fellowship/fells_indexp2.pdf |archivedate=4 October 2006 |accessdate=23 August 2013 |volume=II |date=July 2006 |publisher=[[The Royal Society of Edinburgh]] |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-0-902198-84-5}} ==Early life and education== Murray was born at [[Cobourg, Ontario|Cobourg]], [[Canada West]] on 3 March 1841. He was the second son of Elizabeth Macfarlane and Robert Murray, an accountant. His parents had [[emigrate]]d from Scotland to Ontario in about 1834. He went to school in [[London, Ontario]] and later to Cobourg College. In 1858, at the age of seventeen he returned to Scotland to live with his grandfather, John Macfarlane, and continue his education at [[Stirling High School]]. In 1864 he enrolled at [[University of Edinburgh]] to study medicine however he did not complete his studies and did not graduate.{{cite web|last=Ashworth|first=J.H.|title=Murray, Sir John (1841‚Äì1914)|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35165|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|accessdate=29 December 2014}} In 1868 he joined the whaling ship, ''Jan Mayen'', as ship's surgeon and visited [[Spitsbergen]] and [[Jan Mayen Island]]. During the seven-month trip he collected marine specimens and recorded ocean currents, ice movements and the weather. On his return to [[Edinburgh]] he re-entered the University to complete his studies (1868‚Äì72) in geology under Sir [[Archibald Geikie]]. ==Challenger Expedition== In 1872 Murray assisted in preparing scientific apparatus for the [[Challenger Expedition]] under the direction of the expedition's chief scientist, [[Charles Wyville Thomson]]. When a position on the expedition became available Murray joined the crew as a naturalist. During the four-year voyage he assisted in the research of the oceans including collecting marine samples, making and noting observations, and making improvements to marine instrumentation. After the expedition Murray was appointed Chief Assistant at the Challenger offices in Edinburgh where he managed and organised the collection. After Thomson's death in 1882 Murray became Director of the office and in 1896 published ''The Report on the Scientific Results of the Voyage of HMS Challenger'', a work of more than 50 volumes of reports. Murray renamed his house, on Boswall Road in northern Edinburgh, ''Challenger Lodge'' in recognition of the expedition.Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1905-6 The building now houses St Columba's Hospice. ==Marine Laboratory, Granton== In 1884,[http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst10042.html Overview of Dunstaffnage ik Marine Laboratory] Murray set up the Marine Laboratory at [[Granton, Edinburgh]], the first of its kind in the United Kingdom. In 1894, this laboratory was moved to [[Millport, Isle of Cumbrae]], on the [[Firth of Clyde]], and became the [[University Marine Biological Station, Millport]], the forerunner of today's [[Scottish Association for Marine Science]] at [[Dunbeg|Dunstaffnage]], near [[Oban]], [[Argyll and Bute]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Bathymetrical survey of the fresh-water lochs of Scotland== After completing the Challenger Expedition reports, Murray began work surveying the fresh water [[lochs]] of Scotland. He was assisted by [[Frederick Pullar]] and over a period of 3 years they surveyed 15 lochs together. In 1901 Pullar drowned as a result of an ice skating accident which caused Murray to consider abandoning the survey work. However Pullar's father, Laurence Pullar, persuaded him to continue and gave ¬£10,000 towards completion of the survey. Murray coordinated a team of nearly 50 people who took more than 60,000 individual depth soundings and recorded other physical characteristics of the 562 lochs. The resulting 6 volume ''Bathymetrical Survey of the Fresh-Water Lochs of Scotland'' was published in 1910.{{cite web | url = http://maps.nls.uk/bathymetric/biographies.html | title = Biographies: Bathymetrical survey of the fresh-water lochs of Scotland | last = | first = | date = | website = nls.uk | publisher = National Library of Scotland | accessdate =29 December 2014 }} The cartographer [[John George Bartholomew]], who strove to advance geographical and scientific understanding through his cartographic work, drafted and published all the maps of the Survey. ==North Atlantic oceanographic expedition== In 1909 Murray indicated to the [[International Council for the Exploration of the Sea ]] that an oceanographic survey of the north Atlantic should be undertaken. After Murray agreed to pay all expenses, the Norwegian Government lent him the research ship ''Michael Sars'' and its scientific crew. He was joined on board by the Norwegian marine biologist [[Johan Hjort]] and the ship departed [[Plymouth]] in April 1910 for a four-month expedition to take physical and biological observations at all depths between Europe and North America. Murray and Hjort published their findings in ''The Depths of the Ocean'' in 1912 and it became a classic for marine naturalists and oceanographers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Murray|title=Sir John Murray {{!}} Scottish Canadian oceanographer|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en}} He was the first to note the existence of the [[Mid-Atlantic Ridge]] and of [[oceanic trench]]es. He also noted the presence of deposits derived from the [[Sahara]]n desert in deep ocean [[sediments]] and published a vast number of papers on his findings.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Awards, recognition and legacy== [[File:CirrothaumaMurDraw2.jpg|thumb|The ''Cirrothauma murrayi'' octopus, named after Murray]] * Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] (1877) * Neill Medal from the Royal Society of Edinburgh (1877) * [[Royal Society of Edinburgh#Makdougall Brisbane Prize|Makdougall Brisbane Prize]] from the Royal Society of Edinburgh (1884) * [[Gold Medal (RGS)|Founder's Medal]] from the [[Royal Geographical Society]] (1895) * Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] (1896) {{cite web |url=https://royalsociety.org/~/media/Royal_Society_Content/about-us/fellowship/Fellows1660-2007.pdf |title=List of Fellows of the Royal Society 1660 - 2007 |author= |date=July 2007 |website=royalsociety.org |publisher=The Royal Society |accessdate=1 January 2015}} * [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] (1898) * [[Cullum Geographical Medal]] from the [[American Geographical Society]] (1899) {{Cite journal | URL=https://www.jstor.org/stable/1774739 |title=Meetings of the Royal Geographical Society, Session 1898-99|journal=The Geographical Journal|volume=14|issue=1|year= 1899|pages= 102‚Äì109 }} * [[Clarke Medal]] from the [[Royal Society of New South Wales]] (1900) * [[Livingstone Medal]] from the [[Royal Scottish Geographical Society]] (1910)RSGS memorial to recipients of Livingstone Medal * Vega Medal from the [[Swedish Society for Anthropology and Geography]] (1912) Other awards included the Cuvier Prize and Medal from the [[Institut de France]] and the Humboldt Medal of the [[Gesellschaft f√ºr Erdkunde zu Berlin]].{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article92202859 |title=Sir John Murray motor car accident |author=|date=16 March 1914 |website= trove.nla.gov.au/|publisher=National Library of Australia|accessdate=1 January 2015}} He was president of the Royal Scottish Geographical Society from 1898 to 1904. The ''John Murray Laboratories'' at the University of Edinburgh,{{cite web |url=http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/public/JohnMurray.html |title=The John Murray Laboratories |author= |date= |website=ed.ac.uk/ |publisher=The University of Edinburgh |accessdate=1 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528123837/http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/public/JohnMurray.html |archivedate=28 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }} the ''John Murray Society'' at the [[University of Newcastle upon Tyne|University of Newcastle]] and the [[Scottish Environment Protection Agency]] [[research vessel]], the S.V. ''Sir John Murray''{{cite web |url=http://www.sepaview.com/2014/10/sir-john-murray-the-man-behind-the-name/ |title=Sir John Murray the man behind the name |author= |date=15 October 2014 |website= sepaview.com/|publisher=Scottish Environmental Protection Agency |accessdate=1 January 2015}},, and the [[Murray Glacier]] are named after him. ''[[Cirroteuthidae|Cirrothauma murrayi]]'',{{cite web |url=http://tolweb.org/Cirrothauma_murrayi/20099 |title=Cirrothauma murrayi Chun, 1911 |last1=Young |first1=Richard E. |last2=Vecchione |first2=Michael|date=2003 |website= tolweb.org|publisher=Tree of Life web project|accessdate=1 January 2015}} an almost blind octopus that lives at depths from {{convert|1500|m|ft|abbr=on}} to {{convert|4500|m|ft|abbr=on}} and the [[Murrayonida]] order of [[sea sponge]]s are named after Murray. In 1911, Murray founded the [[Alexander Agassiz Medal]] which is awarded by the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]], in memory of his friend [[Alexander Agassiz]] (1835‚Äì1910). After his death his estate funded the John Murray Travelling Studentship Fund{{cite web |url=http://opencharities.org/charities/207043-64 |title=John Murray Travelling Studentship Fund |author= |date=10 June 2014 |website= opencharities.org/|publisher=Open Charities |accessdate=1 January 2015}} and the 1933 John Murray ''Mabahiss'' Expedition to the Indian Ocean.{{cite web|url=http://www.challenger-society.org/sites/challenger.bangor.ac.uk/files/13_1_8.pdf|title=70 years on... The John Murray Mabahiss Expedition to the Indian Ocean 1933-34|author=|date=2004|website=/www.challenger-society.org|publisher=The Challenger Society for Marine Science|accessdate=1 January 2015}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Death== Murray lived at Challenger Lodge (renamed after his expedition) on Boswall Road in [[Trinity, Edinburgh]] with commanding views over the [[Firth of Forth]].Edinburgh Post Office Directory 1911-12 Murray was killed when his car overturned ten miles west of his home on 16 March 1914 at [[Kirkliston]] near [[Edinburgh]]. He is buried in [[Dean Cemetery]] in [[Edinburgh]] on the central path of the north section in the original cemetery. His home was converted into [[St Columba's Hospice]] in 1977. ==Botanical References== {{Botanist|J.Murray|Murray}} ==See also== * [[European and American voyages of scientific exploration]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== {{commons category|John Murray (oceanographer)}} *{{wikisource author-inline}} * {{Internet Archive author |search=( ("John Murray" OR "Murray, John") AND "1841-1914" )}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060118144008/http://www.mar-eco.no/learning-zone/backgrounders/chemistry/The_Secrets_of_the_Deep On the 1910 Murray and Hjort expedition and the ''Cirrothauma murrayi'' octopus] {{s-start}} {{s-ach|aw}} {{s-bef|before=[[Augustus Gregory]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Clarke Medal]]|years=1900}} {{s-aft|after=[[Edward John Eyre]]}} {{s-end}} {{Polar exploration|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Murray, John}} [[Category:1841 births]] [[Category:1914 deaths]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:People from Cobourg]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in Scotland]] [[Category:People educated at Stirling High School]] [[Category:Canadian people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Scottish biologists]] [[Category:Scottish explorers]] [[Category:Scottish non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Pre-Confederation Ontario people]] [[Category:Royal Medal winners]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cullum Geographical Medal]] [[Category:Recipients of the Pour le M√©rite (civil class)]] [[Category:Scottish marine biologists]] [[Category:Scottish oceanographers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Burials at the Dean Cemetery]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:Limnologists]] [[Category:Scottish naturalists]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2013}} {{Chinese name|[[L√º (surname)|L√º]]}} [[File:Album of 18 Daoist Paintings - 15.jpg|thumb|400px|[[Zhang Lu (painter)|Zhang Lu]]'s painting of L√º Dongbin, early 16th century]] '''L√º Dongbin''' ({{zh|t=ÂëÇÊ¥ûË≥ì|w=L√º Tung-Pin}}) (796 CE-1016 CE) was a [[Tang Dynasty]] Chinese scholar and poet who has been elevated to the status of an [[Xian (Taoism)|immortal]] in the [[Chinese cultural sphere]], worshipped especially by the [[Taoism|Taoists]]. L√º is one of the most widely known of the group of deities known as the [[Eight Immortals]] and considered by some to be the de facto leader. (The formal leader is more likely said to be [[Zhongli Quan]] or sometimes [[Iron-Crutch Li]].) He is also a historical figure who was mentioned in the official history book ''History of Song''. L√º is widely considered to be one of the earliest masters of the tradition of [[neidan]], or internal alchemy. He is depicted in art as being dressed as a scholar and he often bears a [[magic sword|sword]] on his back that dispels evil spirits.
==Character== L√º Dongbin is usually portrayed as a scholarly, clever man with a genuine desire to help people obtain wisdom/enlightenment and to learn the Tao. However, he is often portrayed as having some character "flaws", not an uncommon theme for the colorful Taoist immortals, all of whom in general have various eccentricities: *He is said to be a ladies man, even after (or only after) becoming an immortal ‚Äì and for this reason he is generally not invoked by people with romantic problems. This may also relate to some of the [[Taoist sexual practices|Taoist sexual arts]]. *He is portrayed as having bouts of drunkenness, which was not uncommon among the often fun-loving Eight Immortals. This also parallels several Taoist artists renowned for their love of drinking. *One story relates that early on after becoming immortal, he had a strong temper as a "young" immortal, even deforming a riverbank in a bout of anger. * L√º was also a prolific [[poet]]. His works were collected in the ''[[Quan Tangshi]]'' (Complete Tang poetry).
==Early life== His name is '''L√º Y√°n''', with '''Y√°n''' (Â∑ñ or Â≤© or Âñ¶) being the [[given name]]. D√≤ngbƒ´n is his [[courtesy name]]. He is called Master Pure-[[yin and yang|Yang]] (Á¥îÈôΩÂ≠ê Chunyang Zi), and is also called L√º the Progenitor (ÂëÇÁ•ñ l√º z≈≠) by some [[Taoism|Daoist]], especially those of the [[Quanzhen School]]. He was born in Jingzhao Prefecture (‰∫¨ÂÖÜÂ∫ú Jƒ´ngzh√†o F≈≠) around 796 CE during the [[Tang Dynasty]]
When he was born, a [[Aroma compound|fragrance]] allegedly filled the room. His birthday is said to be on the fourteenth day of the fourth month of the [[Chinese calendar]]. He had been very intelligent since childhood and had many academic achievements. However, according to one story, still unmarried by the age of 20, L√º twice took the top-level [[Imperial examination|civil service exam]] to become a government official, but did not succeed.
In the first year of Tang Baoli (825 CE), he was a scholar for a period of time. He served as a county magistrate twice. Soon he was ruined by officialdom, abandoned his official position and retired to the mountains. Once you traveled to Chang'an Wine Cellar, you will be divorced by Zhengyang's real person. After the "Ten Tests", [[Zhongli Quan]]ÔºàÈçæÈõ¢Ê¨ä Zhong LiquanÔºâ "gives the way of the Golden Dan, because of the law," and finally becomes a fairyÔºåHe died in the Yellow Crane Tower in the 1016 CE in the Northern [[Song Dynasty]]ÔºàÈªÉÈ∂¥Ê®ì hu√°n…°h√®l√≥uÔºâ.
==Yellow Millet Dream== [[File:The Daoist immortal L√º Dongbin crossing Lake Dongting.jpeg|thumb|''The Daoist immortal L√º Dongbin crossing Lake Dongting'', dated to the [[Song dynasty]]]] The legend has it that one night when L√º Yan was in [[Chang'an]] or [[Handan]], he dozed off as his yellow [[millet]] was cooking in a hotel. He dreamed that he took the imperial exam and excelled, and thus was awarded a prestigious office and soon promoted to the position of vice minister (‰æçÈÉé sh√¨l√°ng). He then married the daughter of a prosperous household and had a son and a daughter. He was promoted again and again, and finally became the [[prime minister]]. However, his success and luck attracted jealousy of others, so he was accused of crimes that caused him to lose his office. His wife then betrayed him, his children were killed by bandits, and he lost all his wealth. As he was dying on the street in the dream, he woke up.
Although in the dream, eighteen years had passed, the whole dream actually happened in the time it took his millet to cook. The characters from his dream were actually played by [[Zhongli Quan]] in order to make him realize that one should not put too much importance on transient glory and success. As a result, L√º went with Zhongli to discover and cultivate the [[Tao]]. This dream is known as "Dream of the Yellow Millet" (ÈªÉÁ≤±Â§¢ Hu√°ng Li√°ng M√®ng) and is described in a writing compiled by [[Ma Zhiyuan]] of the [[Yuan Dynasty]].
In volume 82 of [[Song Dynasty]] scholar [[Li Fang (Song dynasty)|Li Fang]]'s ''[[Extensive Records of the Taiping Era]]'', an earlier version of the story, L√º Dongbin was replaced by Student Lu (ÁõßÁîü L√∫ Shƒìng), and Zhongli Quan by Elder L√º (ÂëÇÁøÅ L«ö Wƒìng).
The exact age of L√º Yan when this incident occurred varies in the tellings, from 20 years of age to 40.
==Ten trials of L√º Dongbin== [[File:The Daoist Immortal L√º Dongbin.jpg|thumb|''The Daoist Immortal L√º Dongbin'', a painting from the Ming dynasty]] A story has it that when in Chang An, L√º was tested by Zhongli Quan ten times before Quan took him in as a disciple and L√º subsequently became immortal. These ten trials are described below.
# One day L√º came back from work and found out that his loved one was dying; without sadness or remorse, he started to prepare the dress and coffin necessary for burial, but later his loved one revived and lived on. L√º was still without sadness or joyous feeling. # L√º was selling goods at a market and there came a buyer to bargain with him. After agreeing on the price, L√º handed him the stuff but the buyer refused to pay in full and then walked away. L√º would not argue and let him walk away. # On the first day of the lunar calendar, L√º met with a beggar. After giving him some money, the beggar kept asking for more and threw vulgar words at him. L√º left the scene with a smile. # L√º was once a shepherd. During his tenure a hungry tiger was eyeing the goats under his care. L√º protected the goats by sending them down to the hillside and stood in front of the Tiger. The hungry tiger was awed to see this and left without hurting L√º. # L√º was studying at a small hut on a mountain when a beautiful woman came by and asked if she could stay there for the night since she was lost. That night, this beautiful lady was flirting and tried to get L√º to have sex with her, but L√º was untouched by such temptation. # One day L√º came back to his house and saw that he had been burglarized and lost all his belongings. Without becoming angry he started to work on his farm. As he dug into the ground he found countless pieces of gold. He uncovered the earth without taking a single piece of the gold. # L√º bought some bronze utensils at a market. Upon returning home he realized that all of the utensils were made of gold and he immediately returned them to the seller. # A crazy Taoist was selling medicine on the street, telling people that his magic potion would have one of two outcomes: either 1) the drinker would die on the spot, or 2) the drinker would become immortal. No one would dare to try, except L√º, who bought and tried the potion. Nothing happened to him. # A river was elevated due to heavy rain. L√º and other passengers were on a boat crossing the river. Before reaching the middle of the journey, the weather deteriorated, and most of the passengers except L√º became worried. L√º took it in his stride and never worried about life and death! # L√º was alone at home and suddenly weird things happened. Ghost and monsters were killing each other and wanted to do the same to L√º. Showing no sense of fear, L√º kept on doing his chores without paying attention to them. Another group of devils with blood all over them tried to take L√º‚Äôs life away by saying to L√º that he owed his previous life to them since in past life L√º took his life. Without any fear L√º said ‚Äògo ahead and take my life since I took yours in past life, this is fair and square !‚Äô All of a sudden the sky turned blue and those ghost and devils disappeared. Zhongli Quan (Who happened to be his Teacher and Mentor in Taoist stories) was looking and laughing at him while all these events were happening.
These 10 tests proved that L√º was a pure and dignified person and Master Zhongli was very satisfied and happy to take L√º to Nan San Her Ling to pass his secret to life and subsequently formed a "Zhong-L√º Golden Dan" school of Taoism. But L√º was not too fond of the secret and instead changed his formula for inner peace and benefits more human beings; many until today practiced such path to immortals. This is his major effort and contribution. He is said to have helped many to walk the right path and improve the health and living conditions of many people.
==Stories and legends== [[Image:LuDongbin.jpg|300px|thumb|Statue of L√º Dongbin in the temple in [[Handan]]]] Since the [[Northern Song Dynasty]], there have been many stories and legends that are connected to L√º Dongbin. The stories were usually about L√º helping others to learn the Tao. According to the official [[History of the Song Dynasty]] („ÄäÂÆãÂè≤„Äã), L√º was seen several times visiting the house of [[Chen Tuan]] (Èô≥Êë∂), who was believed to be the first person to present to the public the [[Taijitu]].
The kindness of L√º Dongbin is demonstrated in the [[Chinese proverb]] "dog bites L√º Dongbin" (ÁãóÂí¨ÂëÇÊ¥ûË≥ì g≈èu yƒÉo L«ö D√≤ngbƒ´n), which means an inability to recognize goodness and repay kindness with vice. Some say that the original proverb should actually be "ÁãóÂí¨ÂëÇÊ¥ûË≥ìÔºå‰∏çË≠òÂ•Ω‰∫∫ÂøÉ," stemming from a story about the friendship between Gou Miao (ÁãóÂí¨) and L√º Dongbin, who both did for the other great favors, each of which seemed like a disservice initially, signifying the importance of having faith in one's friends.
According to [[Richard Wilhelm (sinologist)|Richard Wilhelm]], L√º was the founder of the School of the Golden Elixir of Life (Jin Dan Jiao), and originator of the material presented in the book "Tai Yi Jin Hua Zong Zhi" („ÄäÂ§™‰∏ÄÈáëËèØÂÆóÊó®„Äã), or [[The Secret of the Golden Flower]]. Also, according to [[Daoist]] legend, he is the founder of the [[internal martial arts]] style called "Eight Immortals Sword" (ÂÖ´‰ªôÂâë), considered to be one of the martial treasures of [[Wudangshan]].
According to one story, L√º's teacher [[Zhongli Quan]] became an immortal and was about to fly to [[heaven]], while saying to L√º that if he kept practicing the Tao he would also be able to fly to heaven himself very soon. L√º Dongbin replied to his teacher that he'll fly to heaven only after he enlightens all the sentient beings on earth (another story says all his relatives). According to the book "The Eight Immortals Achieving the Tao („ÄäÂÖ´‰ªôÂæóÈÅìÊë∂„Äã)," in his previous [[incarnation]], L√º Dongbin was a Taoist master and the teacher of Zhongli Quan.
According to the Taoist book "History of the Immortals" („ÄäÊ≠∑‰ª£Á•û‰ªôÈÄöÈëí„Äã), L√º is the [[reincarnation]] of the ancient [[Wise old man|Sage]]-[[King]] "Huang-Tan-Shi" (ÁöáË¶ÉÊ∞è).
According to Venerable Hsuan Hua, L√º is one of the transformations of [[Guanyin]] ([[Avalokite≈õvara]]) Bodhisattva.<ref>[http://vbs.drbachinese.org/vbs/vbsgallery/vbs/300/vbs300p014.jpg ÈáëÂâõËè©ÊèêÊµ∑ÂúñÂÉèÁâà Vajra Bodhi Sea, vbs 300]</ref>
==L√º Dongbin and White Peony (Bai Mudan)== One of most popular of L√º Dongbin's legends is his encounter with a prostitute named [[White Peony]] (Bai Mudan)
The most popular version comes from the Journey to the East novel.<ref>Wu Yuantai. [http://open-lit.com/listbook.php?cid=27&gbid=101&bid=3987&start=0 Journey to the East (Dong You Ji)-Chinese text]</ref> It is said that the immortal L√º Dongbin was greatly attracted to White Peony, one of the most beautiful courtesans in [[Luoyang]]. L√º Dongbin slept with her many times but never ejaculated, because he didn‚Äôt want to lose his Yang essence. Unfortunately Lu‚Äôs immortal colleague [[Iron-Crutch Li]] and [[He Xiangu]] taught Mudan how to make him ejaculate by tickling his groin. Finally White Peony successfully made L√º Dongbin ejaculate and absorbed his Yang essence. Later she cultivated herself and became immortal too.
Another version comes from Ba Xian Dedao novel.<ref>[http://guji.artx.cn/article/24620.html Ba Xian Dedao (Eight Immortal obtain enlightenment) Chinese text]</ref> This version is more subtle and there is no sexual intercourse here. One day the immortal L√º Dongbin transforms himself into a handsome scholar and tries to advise the famous prostitute White Peony. In their first encounter White Peony seduces him passionately, but he refuses to sleep with her. In their second encounter, L√º agrees to sleep with her. But as they walk to the bed, L√º suddenly cries that his stomach is painful, and faints. White Peony is very sorry about his condition and calls a doctor using her money (despite her pimp‚Äôs grumbling, who incites her to throw the sick L√º to the road). L√º (who is only pretending to be sick) is very pleased knowing Peony's merciful heart. In their third encounter, L√º Dongbin finally succeeds to persuade White Peony to leave her wayward life. She finally becomes immortal too.
In the opera version, White Peony is changed from a seductive prostitute to the daughter of a drugstore owner. One day L√º Dongbin comes to their store and makes trouble by asking for impossible medicines. Knowing her father's difficulty, Peony meets L√º and answers all of his question. From quarrelling they finally become lovers.
==Modern worship== In 19th- and 20th-century Guangdong, belief in the powers of L√ºzu was strong. In the century after the 1840s, temples were founded which organized [[spirit writing]] seances, festivals for the birthdays of the gods, death rituals, and running schools, clinics, and disaster relief.<ref>Shiga Ichiko, "Manifestations of L√ºzu in Modern Guangdong: The Rise and Growth of Spirit Writing Cults," in Livia Kohn, Harold David Roth, ed., ''Daoist Identity: Cosmology, Lineage, and Ritual'' (Honolulu: University of Hawai'i Press, 2002 {{ISBN|0585464049}}), [https://books.google.com/books?id=_wzwgLAeMWwC&printsec=frontcover&vq=Lu+Dongbin#v=onepage&q=Lu%20Dongbin&f=false p. 200].</ref>
==Media depictions== In the television show ''[[Jackie Chan Adventures]]'', Dongbin was shown to be the immortal who sealed away [[List of Jackie Chan Adventures characters#Shendu|Shendu, The Fire Demon]].
[[Jackie Chan]] portrayed L√º Dongbin in the film ''[[The Forbidden Kingdom]]''.
In Desolate Era, L√º Dongbin is portrayed as one of the True Yang Immortals.
